Rahul Gupta

I'm a final year MD/PhD student at Harvard Medical School applying into internal medicine. I'm passionate about what human biology observed at large scale can teach us about intricate principles of how our cells work. I currently live in Cambridge, MA with my fiancée Carla.

Feel free to read more about my training and my publications.

Research

I have used genetics as a window into several phenomena, including ALS, fatty liver disease, and mitochondrial dysfunction.

For my PhD, I used statistical genetics across hundreds of thousands of people to ask about how mitochondria vary across people and its implications for aging:

  • Is there evidence of nuclear genetic control over common mitochondrial DNA mutations? (Yes, absolutely!)
  • How does variability in mtDNA influence disease risk? (Less than previously reported.)
  • How does common disease heritability partition into organellar proteomes? (Most notably into the nucleus.)

I am fascinated by why different patients experience vastly difference disease courses, why diseases show tissue specificity, and what this can teach us about mechanisms governing human metabolism and biochemistry. I believe that human genetics combined with clever, tissue-specific molecular phenotyping shows tremendous promise.

Other Projects & More

A few friends (who happen to be MD/PhD classmates) and I have recently started a blog as an excuse to hang out and riff on our different perspectives on science, medicine, and more.

When I'm not debating the various takes on the state of the world, I also love cycling and taking pictures, particularly from very high up.
